name: Nikhil Kumar Swain
title: Front End Developer

about.summary: I'm a passionate full stack developer with expertise in modern web technologies. I love building intuitive and performant applications that solve real-world problems.
bio: With over 5 years of experience in web development, I've contributed to projects ranging from lightweight static sites to complex, dynamic web applications.
I'm passionate about creating seamless user experiences, experimenting with modern web tools, and writing clean, maintainable code that brings ideas to life.

experience.description: Leading the frontend development team, implementing new features, and optimizing performance. Creating custom CMS
Developed custom npm libraries. Responsible for the frontend of CODMA a css generator web app.
Built responsive websites and implemented UI designs.

projects.title: E-commerce Platform
projects.description: A full-featured e-commerce platform with product management, cart functionality, and payment processing.

projects.title: Task Management App
projects.description: A collaborative task management application with real-time updates and team features.

projects.title: Weather Dashboard
projects.description: A weather application that displays current and forecasted weather data for any location.

projects.title: Portfolio Website
projects.description: A personal portfolio website showcasing my projects and skills.

projects.title: Recipe Finder
projects.description: An application to search and save recipes based on ingredients and dietary preferences.

projects.title: Budget Tracker
projects.description: A personal finance application to track income, expenses, and savings goals.

funFacts: I once coded for 36 hours straight to win a hackathon!
My first computer was a Commodore 64 that I got from a garage sale.
I can type at a speed of 90 words per minute.
I learned to code by building a game when I was 12 years old.
I collect vintage programming books from the 80s and 90s.
My workspace has 3 monitors and over 20 plants.
I've mentored more than 50 junior developers throughout my career.
My favorite debugging tool is still good old console.log().
I once fixed a critical bug while on vacation at the beach.
